snippet: Many Sunnis in Iraq do not support the Sunni militant group ISIS, but that has not stopped the Iraqi government from attacking them anyway.
abstract: Iraqi army's indiscriminate shelling of Sunni areas, even though many Sunnis do not support militant group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, is only adding to sectarian strife and feeling of many Sunnis that Iraq's Shiite-led government poses the greater threat; overcoming that mistrust is a fundamental challenge facing the new Iraqi government.

byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM, AZAM AHMED and KIRK SEMPLE
byline.contributor: Kareem Fahim reported from Baghdad, and Azam Ahmed and Kirk Semple from Erbil, Iraq. Ali Hazem and Omar Al-Jawoshy contributed reporting from Baghdad, Ahmed Jaf from Erbil, and an employee of The New York Times from Tikrit, Iraq.

lead_paragraph: Many Sunnis in Iraq do not support the Sunni militant group ISIS, but that has not stopped the Iraqi government from attacking them anyway.

headline.main: Sunnis in Iraq Often See Their Government as the Bigger Threat
headline.print_headline: Sunnis in Iraq Often See Their Government as the Bigger Threat

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
